abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome rating of the
            Emergency Multisector Recovery Program Phase II for Angola
            was judged to be moderately satisfactory.  The Bank and
            borrower performance were moderately satisfactory. The risk
            to development outcome was moderate. Significant changes
            included an extension of the closing date.   Several lessons
            were learned. Emergency operations should be designed to be
            as simple as possible, with clear and unambiguous
            implementing arrangements, facilitating prompt
            implementation. Emergency operations in a post conflict -
            oil rich country should also provide a framework for
            parallel finance. Emergency projects are designed to be
            implemented quickly. An emergency operation is designed to
            meet urgent and pressing needs and is usually implemented
            within a period of 36 months. If there is a lengthy delay in
            preparation or approval or effectiveness, consideration
            should be given to converting the emergency operation into a
            more traditional investment operation, focusing on the
            emerging mid-term needs of the country. Key performance
            indicators should always be designed to assess sector
            performance, and should be well matched with the project
            development objectives and adequately monitored during
            project implementation. It is critical to reach agreement
            with the client on a well-designed monitoring and evaluation
            results framework.  The lack of a Midterm Review proved to
            be a missed opportunity for adjustment.  Flexible,
            innovative and coordinated responses are critical in a post
            conflict-oil rich country where the Government can fund many
            activities but lacks the planning and implementation expertise.
